occurrences.line_text: Approching, with bold words and bitter threat,
And shrieking Hububs them approching nere,
Approching nigh, eftsoones his wanton hart
Whom when as Blandamour approching nie,
Yet nigh approching, he them fowle bespake,
Approching nigh, she gins to mend her pace,
Whom when that theefe approching nigh espide,
Approching nigh vnto him cheeke by cheeke,
But soone as they him nigh approching spide,
For that the terme approching fast, required speed.
A storme approching, that doth perill threat,
Who when they nigh approching, had espyde
To whom approching, in that painefull stound
To whom approching, when as she perceiued
Eftsoones he spide a Knight approching nye,
Approching to him neare, his hand he stayd,
With which approching, thus he gan to say;
But when approching neare, he plainely found,
Approching nigh, and murdrous knife well whet,
By this the moystie night approching fast,
Approcht in hast to greet his victorie,
But soone as they approcht with deadly threat,
And to the Castle gate approcht in quiet wise.
Him weening, ere he nigh approcht to haue represt.
Who[m] when they nigh approcht, they plaine descryde
And euer when she nigh approcht, the Doue
Vnto the porch approcht, which open stood;
Who when he nigh approcht, shee mote arede
Till nigh vnto the place at length approcht he has.
To whom as he approcht, he knew anone,
To which as they approcht, the cause to know,
But when he nigh approcht, he mote aread
To whom as they approcht, they gan augment
Approcht, him seemed that the merry sound
As in approuance of his pleasing words.
And lastly in approuance of thy wrong,
And oft approu'd in many hard assay,
Full oft approu'd in many a cruell warre,
Hengist and Horsus, well approu'd in warre,
Approu'd that day, that she all others did excell.
They were, as well approu'd in many a doubt,
And well approu'd in batteilous affray,
Which neuer yet they had approu'd in fight;
Her oft to meet: which better to approue,
She hath ordaind this law, which we approue,
Or else with vs by dint of sword approue,
Then to approue his right with speare and shield.
Or it approue vpon his carrion corse.
Not onely did not his demaund [ap]proue,
And for to make his powre approued more,
Which had approued bene in vses manifold.
Ne thenceforth his approued skill, to ward,
And noble prowesse, which they had approued,
Approued oft in perils manifold,
Ne lesse approued was Cambelloes might,
Approued oft in many a perlous fight.
Shall in this storie find approued plaine;
That I too true by triall haue approued:
With such huge strokes, approued oft in fight,
Which piteous spectacle, approuing trew
Approuing dayly to their noble eyes
As they doe know each can most aptly vse.
Not so th'Arabian Myrrhe did set her mind;
Through boyling sands of Arabie and Ynde;
They bring them wines of Greece and Araby,
And ouer them Arachne high did lift
More subtile web Arachne can not spin,
She was araied all in lilly white,
And naked nature seemely to aray;
That all the house did sweat with great aray:
Aray thy selfe in her most gorgeous geare,
Glistring in armes and battailous aray,
That neuer earthly Prince in such aray
But for to tell the sumptuous aray
A goodly Armour, and full rich aray,
Her louers shape, and cheualrous aray;
She saw bestrowed all with rich aray
A teme of Dolphins raunged in aray,
And wandred in the world in strange aray,
The whiles the maskers marched forth in trim aray.
Like as the sunburnt Indians do aray
And comming home, in warlike fresh aray
And on the other side in fresh aray,
In braue aray and goodly amenance,
Where they before them found in fresh aray
Attyr'd in forraine armes and straunge aray:
And round about him preace in riotous aray.
T'amend what was amisse, and put in right aray.
Arayd in habit blacke, and amis thin,
And gorgeous gold arayd I to thee came;
There all within full rich arayd he found,
Sir knight, aread who hath ye thus arayd,
Arayd in antique robes downe to the ground,
Who rich arayd, and yet in modest guize,
Him hearkned to, and soone her selfe arayd,
And with him brought Priene, rich arayd,
In robe of lilly white she was arayd,
Was fretted all about, she was arayd;
Some like to Puttockes, all in plumes arayd:
And was arayd, or rather disarayd,
The noble Britomartis her arayd,
Ne ye faire Britomartis, thus arayd,
Thus when she had the virgin all arayd,
What mister wight (said he) and how arayd?
And richlier by many partes arayd:
In silken samite she was light arayd,
She saw so rich and royally arayd,
The which was all in lilly white arayd,
Old Cybele, arayd with pompous pride,
As he with golden saddle is arayd;
And royally arayd, Duessa hight,
To tell, what cruell hand hath thus arayd
Together with his Squire, arayed meet:
The rest was all in yellow robes arayed still.
Whiles old Syluanus slept in shady arber sownd.
With nature, did an Arber greene dispred,
With a thicke Arber goodly ouer dight,
Their arbers spoyle, their Cabinets suppresse,
No arboret with painted blossomes drest,
Sitting in couert shade of arbors sweet,
And here and there were pleasant arbors pight,
There was a pleasant arbour, not by art,
With boughes and arbours wouen cunningly,
Like a triumphall Arch, and thereupon
The roofe hereof was arched ouer head,
And arched all with porches, did arize
With shining gold, and arched ouer hed,
But the false Archer, which that arrow shot
Next Archigald, who for his proud disdaine,
But subtill Archimag, that Vna sought
Being in deed old Archimage, did stay
Guyon by Archimage abusd,
Loe yonder he, cryde Archimage alowd,
Till that at length with Archimage they meet:
And loudly cald, Helpe helpe, Ã´ Archimage;
False Archimage prouokt their courage prowd,
And Archimage besought, him that afford,
Yet did false Archimage her still pursew,
Hither (quoth he) me Archimago sent,
But subtill Archimago, when his guests
Where Archimago said a felon strong
And hoarie head of Archimago old,
And said, Why Archimago, lucklesse syre,
The subtill traines of Archimago old;
Ye shall him Archimago find, I ghesse,
Such whenas Archimago them did view,
So had false Archimago her disguisd,
Which when as Archimago heard, his griefe
Who meeting earst with Archimago slie,
Who after Archimagoes fowle defeat,
The whiles false Archimarge and Atin fled apace.
That cunning Architect of cancred guile,
Archt ouer head with an embracing vine,
Is this, then that same water of Ardenne,
As still are wont t'annoy the walled towne,
Whiles you in carelesse sleepe are drowned quight.
Are you in this misformed house to dwell?
Dead is Sans-foy, his vitall paines are past,
T'obserue the sacred lawes of armes, that are assynd.
The yron walles to ward their blowes are weake & fraile.
Into a pure vermillion now are dyde:
When two of three her Nephews are so fowle forlorne?
And downe to Plutoes house are come biliue:
Are wonne with pitty and vnwonted ruth,
That they the woods are past, & come now to the plaine.
And left to losse: his stalking steps are stayde
Mishaps are maistred by aduice discrete,
Both feet and face one way are wont to lead.
The vertues linked are in louely wize:
From which I sprong, from me are hidden yit.
True Loues are ofte[n] sown, but seldom grow on ground.
Are written sure, and haue their certaine date.
Whereof the keyes are to thy hand behight
For those to dwell in, that are chosen his,
Now are they Saints all in that Citie sam,
(Said he) and battailes none are to be fought?
As for loose loues they are vaine, and vanish into nought.
Backe to the world, whose ioyes so fruitlesse are;
So darke are earthly things compard to things diuine.
Now are we come vnto my natiue soyle,
He cryde, as raging seas are wont to rore,
When heauie hammers on the wedge are swaid;
And well arriued are, (high God be blest)
My ragged rimes are all too rude and bace,
Many great Regions are discouered,
Full litle weenest thou, what sorrowes are
But know, that secret vertues are infusd
Their welheads spring, and are with moisture dewd;
Where they are well receiu'd, and made to spoile
In chiefe degree are heaped vp on hye:
The bankes are ouerflowen, when stopped is the flood.
In their beginning they are weake and wan,
Whiles they are weake betimes with them contend:
Are meet, the which doe men in bale to sterue,
Are mortall men so fond and vndiscreet,
Frayle men are oft captiu'd to couetise:
Deriued are, and all this worldes blis
Are not all knights by oath bound, to withstond
Those two the first and last proportions are,
Ne ought I weene are ye therein behind,
You shamefast are, but Shamefastnesse it selfe is shee.
Nourish the flames, which they are warm'd vpon,
They on this rock are rent, and sunck in helplesse wawes.
Are not firme land, nor any certein wonne,
In the wide waters: therefore are they hight
Are deckt with blossomes dyde in white and red,
For these same Monsters are not these in deed,
But are into these fearefull shapes disguiz'd
Now are they come nigh to the Bowre of blis
Said he, These seeming beasts are men indeed,
My senses lulled are in slomber of delight.
champions are defaced.
And honour both; for each of other worthy are.
For pleasing words are like to Magick art,
Of them, that to him buxome are and prone:
More hidden are, then Sunne in cloudy vele;
The which the powres to thee are pleased to reuele.
Then Merlin thus; Indeed the fates are firme,
How can they other do, sith both are bold and blind?
Are wont to cleaue vnto the lowly clay,
Are bound with commun bond of frailtee,
Doe life conceiue and quickned are by kynd:
We both are bound to follow heauens beheasts,
Are fetcht: there is the first seminarie
Of all things, that are borne to liue and die,
And then of him are clad with other hew,
Infinite shapes of creatures there are bred,
Daily they grow, and daily forth are sent
And borrow matter, whereof they are made,
For formes are variable and decay,
Where they doe wither, and are fowly mard:
In balefull night, where all things are forgot;
Are still emongst them song, that far my rymes exceed.
To find him forth: and after her are gone
Ne all are shamed by the fault of one;
Are bound for to reuenge, and punish if they may.
But minds of mortall men are muchell mard,
Said Trompart, You that are the most opprest
where Loues spoyles are exprest.
Yet both are of thy haplesse hand extinct,
Chamber are displayd,
That still are led with euery light report.
They are accorded: Agape
Their wooden ribs are shaken nigh a sonder;
To which all knights with them their Ladies are to bring.
Are quite deuourd, and brought to nought by little bits?
But she as Fayes are wont, in priuie place
As fast as water-sprinckles gainst a rocke are dasht.
Few men, but such as sober are and sage,
Are by the Gods to drinck thereof assynd;
Are wont, before they may to heauen flie,
Are washt away quite from their memorie.
And friends profest are chaungd to foemen fell:
All trauellers tormented are with paine:
But what are you, whom like vnlucky lot
But like a ghastly Gelt, whose wits are reaued,
Sith to his powre we all are subiect borne:
For he whose daies in wilfull woe are worne,
Her words were not, as common words are ment,
I boldly thought (so young mens thoughts are bold)
For ill your goddesse seruices are drest
Let them record them, that are better skild,
The gray eyde Doris: all which fifty are;
For that the seas by her are most augmented.
Witnesse th'exceeding fry, which there are fed,
Such oddes I finde twixt those, and these which are,
Are now transformed into hardest stone:
Of present dayes, which are corrupted sore,
As all things else in time are chaunged quight.
They all are wandred much; that plaine appeares.
And in the same are many trap fals pight,
As when a Dolphin and a Sele are met,
We are not sure they would so long remaine:
Are rapt with wonder, and with rare affright.
When they are all restor'd, thou shalt rest in disgrace.
To you, that are our iudge of equity,
Being desirous (as all Knights are woont)
I rew that thus thy better dayes are drowned
With which the Gods themselues are mylder made:
Right in their wrongs, are rul'd by righteous lore
Are met at spoyling of some hungry pray,
Are dreadded most, and feared for their powre:
Ne none can backe returne, that once are gone amis.
Are wont in Princes courts to worke great scath and hindrance.
Which till this day mongst many liuing are,
Are not all places full of forraine powres?
Like to a rancke of piles, that pitched are awry.
But all in vaine, their numbers are so great,
Are so exceeding spacious and wyde,
For some so goodly gratious are by kind,
I whose vnryper yeares are yet vnfit
As they are wont vnto Latonaes sonne,
And that this Lady, both whose sides are pearst
And did right noble deedes, the which elswhere are showne.
Can remedy such hurts; such hurts are hellish paine.
Are so exceeding venemous and keene,
And as ye soft and tender are by kynde,
They are, which fortunes doe by vowes deuize,
As they are wont in faire sunshynie weather,
Handmaides of Venus, which are wont to haunt
Are Venus Damzels, all within her fee,
They all are Graces, which on her depend,
They are the daughters of sky-ruling Ioue,
And also naked are, that without guile
In whom so many Graces gathered are,
But quite are dimmed, when she is in place.
Whose whelpes are stolne away, she being otherwhere.
So many theeues about him swarming are,
His name Ignaro did his nature right aread.
Aread in grauer wise, what I demaund of thee.
Aread Prince Arthur, crowne of Martiall band?
Sir knight, aread who hath ye thus arayd,
Who better can the way to heauen aread,
But now aread, old father, why of late
From knitting league with him, I you aread;
And if by lookes one may the mind aread,
But Dwarfe aread, what is that Lady bright,
She should aread; many resemblaunces
For dead, I surely doubt, thou maist aread
Aread what course of you is safest dempt,
I can not vnto you aread a right.
Shall death be th'end, or ought else worse, aread.
Yet spake no word, whereby she might aread
Who as he gan the same to him aread,
Doest to thy people righteous doome aread,
Aread (sayd he) which way then did he make?
But now aread, Sir Sergis, how long space,
But then aread, thou gentle chyld, wherefore
Please it you Ladie, to vs to aread,
But yet aread to me, how hight thy Lord,
Aread good sire, some counsell, that may vs sustaine.
But when he nigh approcht, he mote aread
Be it your owne: our rudenesse to your selfe aread.
Who can aread, what creature mote she bee,
But ground he gaue, and lightly leapt areare:
But when his force gan faile, his pace gan wex areare.
That forst him backe recoyle, and reele areare;
His name was meeke Obedience rightfully ared.
All which the Redcrosse knight to point ared,
But vauntage made of that, which Merlin had ared.
To wexe exceeding wroth, and him ared
So hard, this Idole was to be ared,
Yet nathemore his meaning she ared,
That which your selfe haue earst ared so right?
Who when he nigh approcht, shee mote arede
Do lurke, thou certainly to me areed,
And his large bountie rightly doth areed.
Thereby Sir Artegall did plaine areed,
And time and place conuenient to areed,
Then this, Sir Saluage Knight (quoth he) areede;
Who first vs greets, and after faire areedes
Me, all too meane, the sacred Muse areeds
He turned backe, and would haue fled arere;
Was wan and leane, that all her teeth arew,
That Geauntesse Argante is behight,
Of that Argante vile and vitious,
The wondred Argo, which in venturous peece
The noble Argonauts to outrage fell:
The argument of mine afflicted stile:
Argument worthy of Moeonian quill,
This odious argument my rimes should shend,
Euery discourse and euery argument,
Some argument of matter passioned;
Be arguments of a vile donghill mind;
And full of Argus eyes their tailes dispredden wide.
Can guilen Argus, when she list misdonne?
Looke how the Crowne, which Ariadne wore
So thought I eke of him, and thinke I thought aright.
Full hard it is (quoth he) to read aright
To lead aright, that he should neuer fall
That hast my name and nation red aright,
(Their Chieftaine Humber named was aright)
He left two sonnes, too young to rule aright,
Said then the Boteman, Palmer stere aright,
And all their actions to direct aright;
Or whence it sprong, I cannot read aright:
And in each point her selfe informd aright,
Ah (said she) father, I note read aright,
From him my linage I deriue aright,
He did the better counterfeite aright:
That to their willes could them direct aright,
Me from discouering you my name aright:
But somewhat redder, then beseem'd aright,
That when your pleasure is to deeme aright,
Therefore Corflambo was he cald aright,
Them selues her footing to direct aright,
And wested twice, where he ought rise aright.
And each of either take his share aright.
Of things vnseene how canst thou deeme aright,
Within his ballaunce, he could way aright.
For vaine it is to deeme of things aright,
Sayd I not then (quoth shee) erwhile aright,
And witnesse forth aright in forrain land,
Though also those mote question'd be aright,
Or with her owne good will, I cannot read aright.
As Curtesie, to beare themselues aright
Withouten guide, her to conduct aright,
Gotten by spoyle, then purchaced aright.
He could enforme, and them reduce aright,
That could not weigh of worthinesse aright.
What could the Gods doe more, but doe it more aright?
Tho when as all things readie were aright,
Hither came Ioseph of Arimathy,
Before the spouse: that was Arion crownd;
Of Princesse worthy, scarse them bad arise.
So from the ground she fearelesse doth arise,
How with that pensiue Maid he best might thence arise.
And said, Arise thou cursed Miscreaunt,
Arise, and with like treason now maintain
Arise, Sir knight arise, and leaue this cursed place.
Arise, Sir knight arise, and leaue this cursed place.
From heauen to come, or thither to arise,
Him hastie to arise. As one affright
At the well head the purest streames arise:
Out of the fennes of Allan do arise,
From whence it doth, as cloud from sea arise.
Lowly verse may loftily arise,
But th'other rather higher did arise,
Proud Etheldred shall from the North arise,
Vnable to arise, or foot or hand to styre.
Could not arise, the counterchaunge to scorse,
But a third kingdome yet is to arise,
Whence neither greatly hasted to arise,
Harme may arise vnweeting vnto me;
Then letting him arise like abiect thrall,
Then suffred he Disdaine vp to arise,
She at his bidding meekely did arise,
They here ariuing, staid a while without,
Infinite mischiefes of them do arize,
So that no time, nor reason could arize,
Whom still he marked freshly to arize
Betwixt two shadie mountaines doth arize;
When that same Maske againe should forth arize.
And arched all with porches, did arize
In order as it did to him arize.
For when the cause, whence euill doth arize,
Yet nathemore him suffred to arize;
Through which if any grace chaunst to arize
Bearing that precious relicke in an arke
A faithlesse Sarazin all arm'd to point,
Full strongly armd, and on a courser free,
All arm'd with ragged snubbes and knottie graine,
With griping talaunts armd to greedy fight,
And ouer, all with brasen scales was armd,
But his more hardned crest was armd so well,
Whom fyrie steele now burnt, that earst him arm'd,
That erst him goodly arm'd, now most of all him harm'd.
A goodly knight, all armd in harnesse meete,
What direfull chance, armd with reuenging fate,
And was for terrour more, all armd in shyning bras.
That armd with fire, more hardly he mote him withsto[n]d.
Two Paynim knights, all armd as bright as skie,
All threatning death, all in straunge manner armd,
But th'other was Impatience, arm'd with raging flame.
Bright Scolopendraes, arm'd with siluer scales,
Both firmely armd for euery hard assay,
Halfe armd and halfe vnarmd, with them attons:
A comely knight, all arm'd in complete wize,
So weening to haue arm'd him, she did quite disarme.
He was all armd in rugged steele vnfilde,
Armd with his thunderbolts and lightning fire,
Next him was Feare, all arm'd from top to toe,
With murdrous weapons arm'd to cruell fight,
All arm'd to point his chalenge to abet:
She arm'd her tongue, and thought at him to scold;
Streight forth issewd a Knight all arm'd to proofe,
Both strongly arm'd, as fearing one another;
Whom hauing quickly arm'd againe anew,
All arm'd to point, and first the Lists did enter:
With yron wheeles and hookes arm'd dreadfully,
As Wrong, when it hath arm'd it selfe with might?
Whose top was arm'd with many an yron hooke,
All arm'd to point, issuing forth a pace,
All arm'd to point came ryding thetherward,
Himselfe in hast he arm'd, and did him fast pursew.
Sir Calidore him arm'd, as he thought best,
Vpon his manly arme he soone addrest,
He smote off his left arme, which like a blocke
He downe let fall his arme, and soft withdrew
And on his arme a bounch of keyes he bore,
Then to him stepping, from his arme did reach
And who most trustes in arme of fleshly might,
Ylinked arme in arme in louely wise,
Ylinked arme in arme in louely wise,
Vpon her arme a siluer anchor lay,
Else neuer could the force of fleshly arme,
Do arme your selfe against that day, them to confound.
And much ashamd, that stroke of liuing arme
Tho hurling high his yron braced arme,
Fiercely aduaunst his valorous right arme,
And on his arme addresse his goodly shield
And her soft arme lay vnderneath his hed,
So feeble is the powre of fleshly arme.
Of spoyle and murder they gan arme byliue,
From her left arme, to rest in glorious victorye.
His powrelesse arme benumbd with secret feare
Vnder his arme, as seeming wondrous glad,
But not that arme, nor thou the man I reed,
And this the arme, the which that shield did beare,
Let him feele hardnesse of thy heauie arme:
